headline.print_headline: Do We Have the National Will to Fight Cancer?
headline.main: Do We Have the National Will to Fight Cancer? (10 Letters)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-8 Bush Says Democrats 'Undercut' Troops in Iraq The political brinksmanship over Iraq war spending intensified, as President Bush said Democrats had ''undercut the troops'' by passing legislation that ties continued war financing to timelines for the withdrawal of American units. A6 Members of a Republican Congressional delegation to Iraq who were criticized by Iraqis for portraying the security situation in Baghdad as much improved said they were realistic about the dangers that remain there. A6 Pelosi Arrives in Syria Nancy Pelosi, the speaker of the House, arrived in Syria for a visit that is seen as part of an attempt to sway Bush administration policy on Iraq and the Middle East. A6 Blair Hopeful in Iran Dispute Prime Minister Tony Blair said that he was still hoping to secure through diplomatic means the release of the 15 British sailors and marines captured by Iran and that the next 48 hours would be ''fairly critical'' in resolving the dispute. A5 Behind the crisis of Iran's detention of the Britons lies an internal Iranian struggle pitting radicals, aligned with the president, against more pragmatic officials concerned about the country's growing isolation. A5 An Iranian diplomat kidnapped by men wearing uniforms of the Iraqi Security Forces was freed in Baghdad, Iraq's foreign minister said, adding he continued to work to free five other Iranians held by American military forces. A7 Civil Conflict Linked to Youth A study conducted by Population Action International suggests that young populations can contribute to strife. While it is not clear why, the study shows that 80 percent of the civil conflicts that broke out in the 1970s, '80s and '90s occurred in countries where at least 60 percent of the population was under 30. A8 A Political Stand-Off in Ukraine Prime Minister Viktor F. Yanukovich of Ukraine, above, and his cabinet resisted an order by Ukraine's president, Viktor A. Yushchenko, below, to disband Parliament, while thousands gathered near the Parliament building in support of the prime minister. The cabinet, which is loyal to Mr. Yanukovich, responded to the decree by ordering government agencies to disregard it. A8 France Wary of a Paperless Vote While France will be using paperless computer voting for the first time in the coming presidential election, opposition to electronic voting has grown, in part because some are made by the American company whose machines were involved in a disputed Congressional election in Florida last November. A3 NATIONAL A9-12 West Seeks Water As Drought Resumes A Western drought that began in 1999 has resumed after a couple of wetter years. And some $2.5 billion in water projects are planned, the biggest expansion in the West's quest for water in decades. A1 McCain Delays Announcement Lagging in fund-raising and under fire for supporting the Iraq war, Senator John McCain is overhauling his presidential campaign finance operation and delaying the official announcement of his candidacy, his aides said. A1 Debate on Greenhouse Gases A day after the Supreme Court ruled that the federal government had the authority to regulate greenhouse gases, President Bush said he thought the measures he had taken so far were sufficient. But the court's ruling was being welcomed by Congress and the states. A1 Efforts to Reduce Child Obesity The Robert Wood Johnson Foundation plans to spend more than $500 million over the next five years to reverse the increase in childhood obesity, one of the largest public health initiatives ever attempted by a private philanthropy. A9 Romney on the Trail The Republican presidential candidate Mitt Romney dashed across southern New Hampshire, enjoying the attention that has come with his fund-raising haul while trying to raise his profile among voters. A11 New King Documents for Sale A new cache of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.'s papers has surfaced for sale to the highest bidder. A9 Plans to House Veterans The Department of Veterans Affairs and two nonprofit groups in Los Angeles have plans to sign a long-term lease this month that will allow damaged V.A. buildings used as sets for movies and television programs to be transformed into housing with social services and counseling for disabled homeless veterans. A9 Democrats Seek Interview House Democrats requested a private interview with an aide to Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales who has asserted her constitutional right not to testify at a public hearing about the dismissals of United States attorneys. A11 SCIENCE/HEALTH New Risks in Hormone Therapy A new analysis of a large federal study of hormone therapy has found that women in their 50s do not appear to have an increased heart attack risk if they take the drugs. But women in their 60s and 70s who still had hot flashes and night sweats were at increased risk for heart attacks, even if they were not taking hormones. And if these women took hormone therapy, their risk was higher still. A10 NEW YORK/REGION B1-8 New Jersey Is Diverting Billions From Pension Fund New Jersey has been diverting billions of dollars from its pension fund for state and local workers into other government purposes over the last 15 years, using a variety of unorthodox transactions authorized by the Legislature and governors from both major political parties, according to an analysis by The Times. A1 New Tower Near Ground Zero? JPMorgan Chase is in negotiations with state and New York City officials to build a 1.3 million-square-foot skyscraper near ground zero and bring thousands of employees downtown, according to officials. B1 SPORTSWEDNESDAY D1-8 Tennessee Wins Championship Tennessee defeated Rutgers, 59-46, to become N.C.A.A. women's champions, and Coach Pat Summitt won her seventh national title and first since 1998. D1 BUSINESS DAY C1-11 Vermont, a Tax Haven At conferences of the offshore insurance industry, there is often someone promoting Vermont. The state offers companies lucrative tax breaks through unusual insurance arrangements. C1 Pursuing the Tribune Company The news that Sam Zell is becoming the new chairman of the Tribune Company and has no plans to sell any of its individual newspapers hasn't discouraged potential buyers -- and even his rival bidders -- from planning their next move. C1 Russia on Global Positioning Russia and the United States are in the midst of a technological fight over America's monopoly on satellite navigation. The Russian space agency plans to launch eight satellites that would nearly complete the country's own system. C1 Business Digest C2 ARTS E1-12 Biography on Iowa Library Cat In a hotly contested deal, the life story of Dewey, a rescued cat who lived for 19 years in a library in a small town in Iowa, has sold for about $1.25 million to Grand Central Publishing. E3 OBITUARIES A13 Tom Moore A president of ABC Television Network in the 1960s who helped it narrow the ratings gap with NBC and CBS, and who later won five Emmys as head of his own production company, he was 88. A13 EDITORIAL A14-15 Editorials: More than a feeling; it didn't end well last time; shackles on the AIDS program; stay on track. Column: Thomas L. Friedman. Crossword E10 TV Listings E11 Weather C12

headline.main: Do We Have the National Will to Fight Cancer?

docs.abstract: Ten letters comment on Op-Ed articles on fight against cancer; Nancy G Brinker, founder of Susan G Komen for the Cure, says what is lacking is sense of urgency and national will to confront it (Apr 1 Susan Love article); David Perlin, director of Public Health Research Institute, lauds Love's call to change dialogue and approach to cancer research, but bemoans lack of funding; Ken Zaret, leader of one program at Fox Chase Cancer Center, says basic science research is paramount; says much remains unexplored; M J Rosenberg calls for resumption of war on cancer begun in 1971 with sufficient resources to support it; Prof Edwin B Fisher comments on disparities in diagnosis and treatment for minorities, poorly educated and economically poor, citing need for behavioral and public health programs; Patricia Gordon Lamanna calls for study of cumulative effect of environmental carcinogens; Suhael Momin, medical student, prompted by Apr 1 Shannon Brownlee article, calls for more aggressive screening; Albert Henderson, prompted by Brownlee and Ralph W Moss Op-Ed articles, says reduction of Medicare payments is futile attempt to foil profit motive when what is needed are more screenings, trials and therapeutic support; Carol G Feldman praises Betty Rollin (Apr 1 Op-Ed article) for discussion of kinship among survivors; Cindy Barnard, director of Northwestern Memorial Hospital, lauds women who agreed to have extra diagnostic exam as part of study that ultimately revealed benefits of MRI in detecting some breast cancers; drawing
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: As the articles in ''Humans vs. Cancer: Who's Winning Now?'' illustrate (Op-Ed, April 1), there is no shortage of ideas for how to deal with cancer. What appears to be missing, however, is a sense of urgency -- an appreciation of cancer as the grave and growing crisis it is -- and the national will to confront it.

docs.section_name: Front Page; New York and Region
docs.lead_paragraph: $500 Million Pledged To Fight Child Obesity The Robert Wood Johnson Foundation plans to spend more than $500 million over the next five years to reverse the increase in childhood obesity in one of the largest public health initiatives ever tried by a private philanthropy. PAGE A9 The Mayor's Appetite Michael R. Bloomberg has taken on more food issues, and provoked more controversy, than any other New York mayor. DINING, PAGE F1 Tennessee Is a Champ Again Candace Parker scored 17 points and was named the Final Four's outstanding player as Tennessee defeated Rutgers, 59-46, to win the N.C.A.A. women's basketball championship. It was Tennessee's seventh title over all but its first since 1998. SPORTSWEDNESDAY, PAGE D1 SPECIAL TODAY DealBook Mergers and buyouts have been on a record-breaking run, chronicled daily in DealBook, on nytimes.com. In a new special print section, DealBook goes behind the scenes with the most important deal makers. SECTION H Classical Music's New Look Even as classical music takes China by storm, Chinese virtuosos and students are finding a home in the concert halls and conservatories of the West. THE ARTS, PAGE E1

headline.main: A Classroom of Monkey Bars and Slides

docs.lead_paragraph: Play has taken on new forms in these “modern” times:  if children have any free time at all, most playgrounds have become so safe as to be utterly boring.

headline.print_headline: They’re All Bad for You, But Should They Be Illegal?
headline.main: They’re All Bad for You, but Should They Be Illegal?

docs.lead_paragraph: IS it the government’s job to prevent people from engaging in unhealthy behavior? Or is it to give them the best available information so they can decide for themselves what to do? A flurry of bills aimed at banning a range of habits — from smoking in cars with young children to serving partially hydrogenated foods in restaurants — have state lawmakers weighing privacy issues against public health concerns.
